content.intro:
After years in the shadows, Colombia has found the light and taken its place in international tourism. The fourth highest capital in the world, Bogota displays an intriguing personality that is at once mesmerising and progressive.

A metropolis of more than eight million people, the capital city of Colombia, sitting high in the mountains and surrounded by vertiginous Andean peaks, has turned into a tourist destination, as well as the country's epicentre of business, politics, and culture. To the north are the posh quarters, with well-maintained parks and 'Tudor'-style homes: El Chicó, Zona G, and the Parque de la 93, known for their trendy restaurants, and Zona T, the focus for nightlife. In the centre are the Macarena, the Centro Internacional, and the colonial neighbourhood of La Candelaria, the city's cultural centre.

Bogotá's four centuries of history can be read like an open book around the Plaza Bolivar, with its Art Deco, Modernist, Gothic and Renaissance buildings. To capture the rich culture and history, the capital has over 120 museums and galleries. Among them are the Gold Museum, which houses the largest collection of pre-Columbian gold and silverware in the world; MAMBO, the Modern Art Museum, which exhibits paintings, drawings, and sculptures by Colombian and international artists; and the Botero Museum, with its oversized sculptures of ample figures carved by Fernando Botero.

To complete the panorama, an ascent to the Cerro de Monserrate, located at 3,152 metres above sea level, is needed to fully embrace this huge metropolis of 20 districts and more than 1,200 quarters. Bogotá's zest for life is boundless. Enterprising and bustling, it looks to itself with a mixed population that likes to dress, eat, drink, and dance. To travel to Bogotá is to pass from one era to another, from a Baroque church to a neoclassical house on through to a colonial square that still maintains the feel of yesteryear.

Everything is there, the aboriginals, the conquistadors, the revolutionaries and the liberators. But even though Bogotá's reputation has improved, it would be naïve to imagine that the entire centre is safe. It is best to know where you are going and to not walk alone in the streets at night.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Bogota

seoData.seoTitle: Bogotá, golden capital city – Bogotá Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: After years in the shadows, Colombia has found the light and taken its place in international tourism. The fourth highest capital in the world, Bogotá displays an intriguing personality that is at once mesmerising and progressive.
seoData.seoKeywords: Bogotá, Colombia, Air France, Airplane, Travel, Tourism, Visit, Guide, El Chicó, Zona G, Zona T, Parque de la 93, La Macarena, Centro Internacional, La Candelaria, Plaza de Bolívar, Cerro de Monserrate, MAMBO

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Bogota

content.title: Local by Rausch, a gourmet adventure

introduction.small: What if you were to take a delicious detour by one of Bogotá's best loved restaurants? Then head to the Rausch brothers'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Local by Rausch, a gourmet adventure

paragraphs.text:
The Colombian-born Rausch brothers are famous with gourmet eaters worldwide for the high-quality cuisine they serve. Together, Jorge and Mark make a case for the richness of Colombian gastronomy, in a welcoming and eclectic restaurant located in the heart of Bogotá. Whether at the dining room, lounge bar or outside terrace, the best seat awaits you.

Local by Rausch adds a daring and modern touch to Colombian traditional recipes, offering the clientele a chance to try sophisticated dishes cooked with fresh and local products. In the kitchen, the two brothers will cook a meal with dedication and creativity, according to your wishes: shrimp cocktail in tomato sauce, tuna tartare in avocado cream and quinoa, or grilled octopus in annatto oil. For dessert, there is an abundance of flavours available… Take a long look at the menu, there are no holds barred!

Local by Rausch
Carrera 11A # 89 - 38
Bogotá

+57 (1) 756 1202

http://hermanosrausch.com/local.html

Menu: around 60,000 COP

content.title: Selina, chic and trendy hostel in La Candelaria

introduction.small: Ideally located in Bogotá's historical district, Selina reflects the atmosphere prevalent in the neighbourhood: bohemian, charming and authentic.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Selina, chic and trendy hostel in La Candelaria

paragraphs.text:
After successful openings in the Chapinero and Parque 93 districts, Selina sets up a new home amidst La Candelaria, Bogotá's historical part of town. Between Art Deco, Baroque looks and a Spanish colonial style, the hostel settled in an old building with exposed brick walls. The decoration of both private rooms and dormitories has been carefully thought out, with trendy bohemian furniture, navy blue tiles on the bathroom floors and raw wood used everywhere, from the floorboards to the headboards.

The hostel's facades display gorgeous works of street art. The large and colourful frescoes represent various aspects of Colombian life and add some extra charm to the already stylish building. At the centre of the establishment, a patio, replete with tables and bench seats, allows mobile workers and passing visitors to enjoy a moment of peace and quiet in this very lively neighbourhood.

Selina
Calle 11 #343
La Candelaria
Bogotá

+57 (1) 653 2680

www.selina.com/colombia/la-candelaria-bogota/

Rooms: dormitory bed from 28,369 COP, private bedroom from 179,672 COP

content.title: Azahar Parque 93, the science of senses

introduction.small: Any time is the right time for coffee! At Azahar Parque 93, you will softly discover the delicious skills of Colombian coffee producers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Azahar Parque 93, the science of senses

paragraphs.text:
As Colombian coffee bushes blossom and fields of grass take on opaline hues, Azahar Coffee Company are on a mission to discover the greatest plantations of the country. Their goal is to spread the word about the best roast Colombian coffee ever, all around the world. Concerned with forging long-lasting and open relationships with local producers, the Colombian exporter pays strict attention to the quality of the coffee it is being offered. Thus, they shed a light on the work of the small agricultural structures they meet along the way.

This spirit of fair trade marked the birth of Azahar Parque 93 (one of the brand's various establishments), which in no time has become one of Bogotá's most popular coffee places. At the break of day, pair your latte, espresso, macchiato or cappuccino with an arepa (cornbread speciality from Venezuela and Colombia) in grilled cheese and pico de gallo. Later in the day, pair your coffee with chicken legs, a pumpkin mash, arugula and honey. That is, unless the combination of bacon slices, creamy goat cheese and marinated vegetables of the Azahar Burger catches your fancy first!

Azahar Parque 93
Calle 93b No. 13 - 91
Bogotá

+57 (1) 739 1661

https://azaharcoffee.com/en/

Menu: around 40,000 COP for breakfast, 60,000 COP for lunch

content.title: Vegetables in the spotlight at Makeout Colombia

introduction.small: While people from the Andes usually eat a lot of meat, Makeout Colombia rides the opposite wave and serves a 100% plant-based cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vegetables in the spotlight at Makeout Colombia

paragraphs.text:
At first glance, everything would lead you to believe that Makeout Colombia is a neo-bistro like many others, with lovely bench seats, velvet armchairs, rows of wooden tables and a winter garden. Trust us, it is not. The concept is simple: no animal product is being served; only "plant-based food" is being prepared in the kitchen. As a matter of fact, Matthew Kenney, the most influential American chef on the vegan scene, set up home in Bogotá with his Makeout franchise restaurants. An alternative to meat-based diets, the menu offers falafels, sunflower seeds pesto, zucchini tagliatelle and even a plant burger that is so good you will forget there is no meat between the buns. A bite of creamy lemon cheesecake is a great note to end the meal on.
You may also go to Makeout Colombia for breakfast and enjoy an acai bowl with almond milk and homemade granola. After eating at Makeout, you will never see vegetables in the same light!

Makeout Colombia
Carrera 9, n° 81-18
Bogotá

+57 (1) 300 0390

www.makeoutcolombia.com

Menu: around 43,000 COP

content.title: Casa Santa Clara, traditional cuisine on the heights of Bogotá

introduction.small: At the very peak of Monserrate, overlooking the Colombian capital, Casa Santa Clara offers local gourmet cuisine inside of a typical old house.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa Santa Clara, traditional cuisine on the heights of Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by abundant Colombian flora, Casa Santa Clara is a true haven of peace. Far from the bustle of Bogotá, tucked on the heights of Monserrate mountain, this gigantic structure is reminiscent of 1960s homes with its white facade laced with numerous doors and windows. Inside, the simple and warm decoration - old wood parquet flooring, black and white photos of the capital hung on the walls - adds something to an even more authentic character. With a panoramic view of the city as a backdrop, order one of the country's traditional dishes, such as chicken with passion fruit sauce and coconut rice or the grilled fillet of beef served with Creole fries, guacamole and oven-baked yucca. In the evening, dinner is accompanied by regional music concerts. Finish the meal on a high note by having a seat on a bench, facing the view, and allow your mind to wander before the city's night lights.

Casa Santa Clara
Cerro De Monserrate
Bogotá

+57 (1) 745 4628

www.restaurantecasasantaclara.com

Menu: around 55,000 COP

content.title: Chichería Demente, the best meat in Bogotá

introduction.small: Chichería Demente reinvents Colombian gastronomy in a unique and unusual fashion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chichería Demente, the best meat in Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
Located on an ancient farm built in 1906 in the heart of the capital, Chichería Demente is the new go-to restaurant when it comes to quality grilled meat. Even though the premises have been entirely restored, they have not lost the classical elements from the time. You will catch sight of the flames cooking food in a wood-oven that sits right in the middle of the gigantic open-plan kitchen. As for the decoration, the brick walls and exposed beams on the ceiling give the main dining area a firmly rustic feel.
You will thus be able to try all sorts of meat, from Angus beef ribeye to pork ribs and roasted lamb. They are all deliciously tender as a result of perfectly mastered cooking methods. The must-try dish remains the conejo jerk, rabbit cooked with hot peppers, carrots and radish. Care for a drink? Then take a seat at the bar to enjoy, in moderation of course, a sophisticated cocktail, a cold beer or fruity liquors. An invigorating and gourmet break!

Chichería Demente
Calle 69, n° 15-08
Bogotá

+57 320 937 3488

www.facebook.com/chicheriademente/

Menu: from 42,000 COP

content.title: Maloka Interactive Center, for the love of science and technology

introduction.small: Since 1998, a fabulous theme park has been dedicated to science and technology. Welcome to the Maloka Interactive Center!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maloka Interactive Center, for the love of science and technology

paragraphs.text:
To the west of Bogotá, inhabitants and tourists alike jostle at the entrance to a vast building with an astonishing design. Built on the initiative of the Colombian Association for the Advancement of Science, the Maloka Center opened its doors nearly two decades ago and now houses a stunning 3D domed cinema, nine different exhibition rooms and more than 300 interactive modules spread over 17,000 sqm. Over the years, with growing success they have added a boutique, a restaurant, a café and a public square.

Before becoming the largest institution of its kind in Latin America, the Maloka project brought together scientists, creators and teachers with the same desire to pass on their knowledge. A successful idea: between biology, robotics, chemistry, geology, optics, or mechanics, the centre provides the keys to an understanding of modern physical, natural and technological phenomena, through short and feature films, as well as through gastronomy and music.

Maloka Interactive Center
Carrera 68D, 24A-51
Ciudad Salitre, Fontibón
Bogotá

+57 (1) 427 27 07

www.maloka.org

Carrera 68D, 24A-51
Ciudad Salitre, Fontibón
Bogotá

+57 (1) 427 27 07

www.maloka.org

content.title: Colombian coffee trees: the scent of perseverance

introduction.small: In the western region of Bogotá, the coffee zone of Colombia stretches as far as the eye can see in verdant and fragrant valleys.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colombian coffee trees: the scent of perseverance

paragraphs.text:
Coffee beans were brought to Colombia by the Jesuits in 1730, unless it was a traveller from Guyana who passed through Venezuela. Since 2011, the cultural landscape of coffee in Colombia has been declared a World Heritage Site by UNESCO. At the foot of steep mountains, bamboo forests give way to plantations of this black gold.

A few hours from Bogotá, Colombians shape the environment with their hands tired by hard work: Manizales, Armenia and Pereira are the three corners of the ‘coffee triangle'. When the orthogonal plots are green on the mountainsides and rugged plains, the drupes waltz into the workers' baskets and burlap cloths, the mules trample the narrow jungle paths and the horses gravitate around the haciendas. Come over to see the Colombian harvests from October to February, and again from April to June.

articles.topic: the experience of andrés carne de res

content.title: MUST-GO-TO

introduction.small: Take the trip to Andrés Carne de Res to see Colombian culture in all its glory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MUST-GO-TO

paragraphs.text:
Just ten minutes from Bogotá, Andrés Carne de Res is much more than just a restaurant. It is a real bric-a-brac paradise with an inimitable style, where you will have a date with Colombia's very soul. In 1982 when it opened, the place was just a small establishment with about ten seats known only to local inhabitants. Today, it has grown and attracts a crowd of customers from Bogotá along with curious tourists.

During your stay in Bogotá, it is imperative that you spend at least one of your evenings in this eccentric steakhouse, with its surrealist and colourful decor. As for the menu, you will discover a wide choice of Latin American dishes: empanadas, pepper steak served with mashed potatoes and red wine sauce, chicken ajiaco with rice, avocado, banana, capers, cream and coriander. For party-goers, you can dance until the end of the night right outside.

Andrés Carne de Res
Calle 3, 11-56
Hogar Encendido
Chia
Bogotá

+57 (1) 861 2233

www.andrescarnederes.com

Menu: around 75,000 COP

content.title: La Fama Barbecue: grilled meats have pride of place

introduction.small: A ‘BBQ' in the great American tradition, and a popular address for meat lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Fama Barbecue: grilled meats have pride of place

paragraphs.text:
Reflecting the taste of Bogotános for the North American diet, La Fama Barbecue, with its dominant meat menus, is emerging as one of the most fashionable addresses in Bogota.

The restaurant smells of organic meats, smoked for eight hours before being grilled, and has a burning desire to provide you with good products and new journeys in taste that rekindle the gustatory flame. On the menu you will find chicharrones (fried pork belly), chicken wings, a half-chicken slowly cooked on a barbecue or papas criollas (potato croquettes), all with homemade sauces, onions, and spicy sliced coleslaw. For a Colombian touch, choose the morillo or costillas steak, or delicious ribs. Great grilled meats indeed, but it is above all a quality product that the marinades or sauces do not hide, but enhance.

This is an urban barbecue that is never stingy with festive happenings.

La Fama Barbecue
Calle 65 Bis, #4-51
Bogotá

+57 (1) 644 77 66

https://lafama.com.co/

Menu: from 46,000 COP

content.title: The Botanical Garden: floral observatory

introduction.small: North of the Simon Bolívar Park, the 'Central Park' of Bogotá, you will find a lush tropical garden and the ideal place for discovering Colombian flora.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Botanical Garden: floral observatory

paragraphs.text:
The Jardin Botanico José Celestino Mutis, is named after the Spanish scientist who led the first botanical expedition organised in the New World. Beyond being a lush garden, it is the ideal place to discover Colombian flora, which is numerous and diverse, as well as the country's wildlife.

Founded in 1955 on 20 hectares, it has more than 2,300 domestic and exotic species, classified into 35 ecological zones, according to warm, dry, and wet climates. The arboretum is rich in bromeliads, orchids, ornamental flowers, species typical of tropical and desert areas, plants adapted to Amazonian humidity, a rose garden with 73 species, as well as exceptional palm trees and lotus plants. The greenhouse recreates the different climates encountered in Colombia, from rainforests, cloud-touched mountains, and snow-capped Andean peaks to the Paramo (a rare ecosystem that exists in a few countries only), where the visitor can feel the different temperature changes. A genuinely green experience!

José Celestino Mutis Botanical Garden
Calle 63, 68-95
Bogotá

+57 (1) 437 70 60

www.jbb.gov.co

content.title: Emerald Museum, in the land of Esmeralda

introduction.small: Not far from the Gold Museum, another venue awaits, at once didactic and spectacular, dedicated to this precious Colombian stone.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Emerald Museum, in the land of Esmeralda

paragraphs.text:
The eastern side of the Cordillera of the Colombian Andes has revealed some of the world's finest emeralds. The fervour of Colombians for this gem does not date from yesterday. In the 13th century, the Colombian Incas mined the earth in search of emeralds to decorate their temples. The arrival of Spanish settlers marked the beginning of a more sustained rate of extraction, particularly in the Muzo Mine located north west of Bogotá.

This small but fascinating museum invites you to go through a mine corridor, along which you learn the steps of the formation process and stone extraction, before admiring hundreds of rough and polished stones, some having passed through the hands of jewellers. You will want to pause in front of the most famous emerald in the world, the Devonshire, a jewel of over 1,380 carats offered by Emperor Pedro the First of Brazil to Lord Devonshire in 1830.

As a bonus, there is a spectacular panorama of the city on the 23rd floor.

Museo Internacional de la Esmeralda
Calle 16, 6-66
Bogotá

+57(1) 316 832 1180

https://www.museodelaesmeralda.com.co/

content.title: Avenida Jiménez: the green gem

introduction.small: An attraction in itself that separates the old city from its commercial centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Avenida Jiménez: the green gem

paragraphs.text:
While we are in the neighbourhood, a brief look at the different displays of the emerald vendors is required. From 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., the Esmeralderos discuss and bargain with potential buyers. The gemstone comes in all forms, sizes, and colours, in the rough or finely cut, unassembled or set, but always of a dreamlike green.

Once you have haggled and are ready to buy your emerald (should you be so bold, as one really needs to know one's way around here), claim an authenticity certificate filled out by the seller, in order to establish the actual value. For quality emeralds, count on prices 10-50% lower than the prices charged in Europe. Today, emeralds mined in the Colombian provinces are transported by helicopter to Bogotá, where they are assigned a market value. It is believed that 60% of the emeralds on the gem markets come from Colombian mines.

www.colombia.travel/en/where-to-go/andean/bogota/activities/stroll-down-environmental-hub

content.title: Matiz, a real chef

introduction.small: The home of one of Bogotá's current best chefs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Matiz, a real chef

paragraphs.text:
Since it opened in 2004, the Matiz has been a hit. The gourmet creations of the new chef Arnau Beyrens Caballero and the friendly approach of the place make it one of the best addresses in the Colombian capital. It offers a sesame-crusted tuna tataki with sautéed vegetables and cashews, a lobster tail and stir-fried noodles paella-style, duck breasts in mango or a slowly cooked shoulder of lamb served with Creole tubers.

By combining traditional flavours and a sense of European innovation, the chef creates inspired menus, accompanied by the great selection of wines that his talented team will help you choose from. This master has made 'revisited traditional' the flavour of the moment. With its classic and simple decor, the dining room opens onto a lovely outdoor terrace and a waterfall.

Matiz
Calle 95 # 11A-17
El Chicó
Bogotá

+57 (1) 520 20 03

www.matizrestaurante.com

Menu: around 103,000 COP

content.title: Bolívar's Quinta, former house of the Libertador

introduction.small: A historical museum at the foot of Monserrate.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bolívar's Quinta, former house of the Libertador

paragraphs.text:
This 19th-century villa was given to Simon Bolívar in 1820 to thank him for having liberated the country. He remained there for five years of his presidency, using it as a place of business and pleasure, since it was here that he lived his love affair with Manuela Sáenz, his mistress and partner in the struggle for independence. In 1850, Bolivar offered it to his friend José Ignacio París. Successively a girls' school, a brewery, a tannery, and a mental hospital, it became a museum in 1922. Restored, it has the original French style that its master gave it, period furniture, and original furnishings. There is a lounge, games room, Bolívar's bedroom, a kitchen, and a collection of personal items, including photographs, dishes, furniture with secret compartments, and his famous sword. This Venezuelan aristocrat and military man lived many adventures and exciting stories that are recounted to visitors.

Quinta de Bolívar
Calle 21, 4A - 30 Este
Bogotá

+57 (1) 342 4100

www.quintadebolivar.gov.co

content.title: Cerro de Monserrate, a symbol of Bogotá

introduction.small: A place of pilgrimage, it allows you to measure the immensity of the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cerro de Monserrate, a symbol of Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
Rising to the east of the centre, about 1.5 km from La Candelaria, Monserrate is visible from almost everywhere. At more than 3,000 metres high, its peak offers an incredible view of the 1,700 square kilometres of the capital. At the top is a white church and the sanctuary devoted to 'El Señor Caídode Monserrate', (Christ fallen from the cross). It has been a place of worship since 1657 and is also a place of pilgrimage visited by thousands of Colombians every year, especially because of the statue of El Señor Caído next to the altar, which dates from 1650, which has been credited with many miracles.

The summit is accessible by funicular or cable car and takes about ten minutes. It is also accessible on foot by climbing the 1,500 steps, which takes between 60 and 90 minutes. Adepts have privileged access to the trail at dawn, in order to run it, a popular pastime on the weekend.

Cerro de Monserrate
Carrera 2 E No. 21-48
Bogotá

+57 (1) 284 57 00

www.cerromonserrate.com

content.title: La Zona Rosa: fiesta in Bogotá

introduction.small: North of the city, the nightlife district, with all its lights, shines until dawn.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Zona Rosa: fiesta in Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
In Bogotá, nightlife is hectic. Only one rule applies throughout the year: dance to exhaustion, from midnight to dawn. It is here that all the most fashionable nightclubs may be found, including El Goce Pagano, which is one of the best places to dance salsa; Salomé Pagana, an institution for learning and progressing; and El Salto del Angel, a rumba disco restaurant bar for partying all night.

A laboratory for all trends, the Zona Rosa resonates in the evening with nightlife rhythms. Whether you love salsa, rumba, or jazz, the choice is vast. But whatever happens, around 8:00 p.m., the music invades the scene, and the party begins. And on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday nights, irresistible music arrangements will get you up from your table. It is highly recommended to book on the weekend, as the Bogotános are out in force, swaying their hips to Latin rhythms until late at night.

El Salto del Angel
Carrera 13 # 93 A – 45
Bogotá

+57 (1) 654 54 55

www.saltodelangel.com.co

content.title: Four Seasons Casa Medina Bogotá: a historical hotel

introduction.small: The Casa Medina is a chic must for many travellers. Its colonial inspired architecture is the work of architect Santiago Medina Mejía.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Seasons Casa Medina Bogotá: a historical hotel

paragraphs.text:
This hotel gem under the Four Seasons flag is located in the Zona G, the financial and commercial district of Bogotá, which is an ideal location for touring the city. This listed building with its magnificent facade known throughout the town, is now beautifully renovated and the success is unanimous.

Here, all the architectural pieces were restored and enhanced with more contemporary elements and design materials. Comfort is premium in the 62 spacious and luxurious rooms. Some have original fireplaces or wood carvings, and all are decorated in a warm style playing on harmonies using wood. Around the lobby and restaurant, the large wrought-iron staircase designed by the architect in 1946, remains an architectural splendour. Its line and envious curve draws glances as much as the signature restaurant, serving Spanish cuisine in an elegant dining room or on the terrace around the tapas bar. The luxury spa offers four massage rooms with many personalised treatments to ensure your total wellness, as well as high quality service.

Four Seasons Casa Medina Bogotá
Avenida Carrera 7, 69A-22
Bogotá

+57 (1) 325 79 00

www.fourseasons.com

Rooms: from 1,309,500 COP

content.title: Bogotá Beer Company, for hops lovers

introduction.small: Beer lovers will relish the micro-brewed draught beers that change with the seasons.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bogotá Beer Company, for hops lovers

paragraphs.text:
Colombians love beer, all beers, from the popular Aguila to Club Colombia, which has more taste.

Bogotá Beer Company is one of the few microbreweries in town. With an English pub atmosphere and a young and trendy clientele, the company has 12 addresses in the capital, but the best is the one in the Zona Rosa. It produces eight beers, including Candelaria Clasica, with a light English-style, and Tenquendama Negra, which is close to Guinness, as well as an ale and a lager, served in all the trendy pubs in Bogotá.

For those who may doubt, the little glass bottle no longer just accompanies pizza, but is drunk with ceviche. Because the foam is refined and the aromatic subtleties go beyond the simple division of lager vs. ale, enjoy the wide range of tropical fruits that bloom here. The Bogotá Beer Company has become an institution with a Colombian accent.

Bogotá Beer Company
Carrera 12 # 83-33, Zona Rosa
Bogotá

+57 (1) 742 9292

Menu: around 18,000 COP

content.title: Four Seasons Bogotá, the newborn

introduction.small: Replacing the former Hotel Charleston, the Four Seasons Bogotá has a great reputation. 64 luxurious rooms can be found in the most fashionable district of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Four Seasons Bogotá, the newborn

paragraphs.text:
A dream location and extreme refinement mark this contemporary setting in the heart of the Zona T. This is the most fashionable district of Bogotá, with its trendy boutiques, chic restaurants, and crowded bars.

Just like an upscale and cosmopolitan boutique hotel, the 64 rooms here have zero faults, having been thought through in every detail in terms of decor, facilities, and the latest available technologies. The service is impeccable in the chic Robata Restaurant, which is the gourmet Japanese restaurant in the hotel. The menu features authentic and tasty traditional cuisine with grilled dishes, and a sushi bar featuring a wide selection of sakes and Japanese beers. After eating healthy and refined dishes in a modern design, guests can also enjoy the spa and fitness centre.

A serene atmosphere is guaranteed.

Four Seasons Bogotá
Carrera 13 No 85-46
Bogotá

+57 (1) 325 7900

www.fourseasons.com/bogota

Rooms: from 1,170,000 COP

content.title: La Candelaria, colonial promenade

introduction.small: The historical centre with its cobbled streets, colourful houses, and Baroque churches groups together all the beautiful sites of Bogotá.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Candelaria, colonial promenade

paragraphs.text:
Planted on the mountainous slopes of Monserrate, La Candelaria has maintained the atmosphere of a colonial neighbourhood. It is a maze of narrow, steep streets where it is easy to get lost lined with rainbow coloured houses, carved wooden balconies, Baroque churches, squares, and a plethora of cafés and restaurants to experience.

The carefully preserved colonial buildings are home to museums and hotels scattered among the three-century-old houses, churches, and convents. The oldest neighbourhood of Bogotá, declared a historical monument in 1963, also contains much of the city's tourist offerings: the red-and-white Byzantine-inspired Gothic church Iglesia del Carmen; the Independence Museum, where you can learn all about the famous vase that started it all; the Casa de Narino; the Luis Angel Arango Library, which is the largest in the country everything is concentrated around four city blocks. Make a special point of entering the churches you find along your way.

www.lacandelaria.info

content.title: Sofitel Bogotá Victoria Regia, a safe bet

introduction.small: Located in the north of the city, in the exclusive Zona Rosa, the Sofitel Bogotá Victoria Regia boasts an excellent location close to restaurants, shops, and galleries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Bogotá Victoria Regia, a safe bet

paragraphs.text:
Its name, Sofitel Bogotá Victoria Regia, is a tribute to the beauty and elegance of the Colombian water lily floating on the Amazon, an admired plant for its resplendence and the strength of its leaves.

Like it, the hotel is adorned with elegance and character. Designed by Colombian architect Miguel Soto, this place is a hyphen between the French and Colombian culture. Thus, public spaces offer a classic and modern elegance, including the gourmet restaurant Basilic where Mediterranean-derived cuisine is served in a chic Baroque decor. Relax at the comfortable bar in an atmosphere of refinement, which is a pleasure shared in the 102 luxurious rooms and five suites, which are pampering and intimate. They are dressed in velvet fabric and lined with warm colours in a harmony of purple, plum, and mauve. Continuing the Mediterranean theme, the designer bathroom has L'Occitane products, offering a preview of the massages and treatments given at the spa.

An invitation to let go in a city in perpetual motion.

Sofitel Bogotá Victoria Regia
Carrera 13, 85-80
Bogotá

+57 (1) 646 63 90

https://sofitel.accorhotels.com/en/hotel-0561-sofitel-bogota-victoria-regia/index.shtml

Rooms: from 420,000 COP

content.title: The Click Clack Hotel: festivity guaranteed!

introduction.small: A vibrant designer boutique hotel, for customers who love music, entertainment, and night clubs.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Click Clack Hotel: festivity guaranteed!

paragraphs.text:
Do you like festive, high-tech places? Don't hesitate, then, to book into this rock'n'roll temple. The Click Clack Hotel, located in the Zona Rosa, concentrates the best of hedonism over 11 high-design floors. It is the meeting place for DJs, photographers, and top models, who rush in for dinner on the roof and dance until dawn.

At the Apache restaurant, you can taste the best burgers with a bonus: a dazzling view of the city while listening to hits of the local Top 50. On the ground floor, the second restaurant celebrates ethnic-chic around a menu of tapas and salads. On the arty side, the decor includes Space Invaders motifs in the elevator and abstract paintings in the rooms, of which there are 60 in total, all decorated in a minimalist style and classified by size. You do not choose a junior suite but an M, L or XL room. Some have large glass walls with a dazzling view of the city. At the cutting edge of trends, they benefit from high-end equipment so that the quality bed, fabulous lighting, and the rain shower, can all be piloted by tablet. Your stay here promises to be fun!

The Click Clack Hotel
Carrera 11 # 93 -77
Bogotá

+57 (1) 743 04 04

https://clickclackhotel.com

Rooms: from 239,000 COP

content.title: Highly colourful markets

introduction.small: This is an obligatory Sunday appointment and an authentic encounter with the very essence of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Highly colourful markets

paragraphs.text:
Sunday in Bogotá is full of surprises and rare finds for those who wish to bargain hunt in one of the many outdoor flea markets. From old records to old cameras, there is everything at the San Alejo Market, one of the city's cultural and tourist heritage sites, located on the main street at Carrera 7, where 300 exhibitors gather. Another popular place is the Usaquén Flea Market, located in the central square on Calle 119 and Carrera 6. It brings together artists, craftsmen, and retailers of all kinds.

There you can find very good prices for the creamy dulce de leche of the region, stunning multi-coloured scarves and multifaceted shawls, unique leather shoes, and refreshing guanábana, lulo, and pitaya fruit juices. Unless you prefer the Paloquemao Market, where you can taste exotic flavours and make the purchases needed to prepare one of the Bogotános' favourite dishes.

San Alejo flea market
Carrera 7 #2470
Bogotá
+57 1 283 1073

Usaquén flea market
Calle 119 & Carrera 6
Bogotá

Paloquemao produce market
Calle 19, #25-04
Bogotá

content.title: The Monkey House: a temple of beer

introduction.small: A traditional English pub where you can choose between more than 100 beers from around the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Monkey House: a temple of beer

paragraphs.text:
Another trendy address, the Monkey House is where Bogotá aficionados gather together and drink beer. It's a drink that makes one particularly sociable, it seems. Those who appreciate the cosy atmosphere of English pubs will be in their element between the brick walls of this well-known establishment. You will find a wide range of beers from around the world: the Netherlands, Germany, Belgium... the pub has more than ten draught lagers and dark beers, as well as a traditional menu. We suggest you mingle with the expat crowd over a pint on a football game night, as it will be sure to be animated.

On weekends, groups of friends meet here regularly in a lively convivial atmosphere. You will appreciate the friendly staff, the cheerful ambience, and the always-tempting menus of this traditional pub. Between hops, malts, and yeast, and high or low fermentation, all tastes are catered for.

The Monkey House
Calle 70a, 8-55
Bogotá

+57 (1) 805 86 48

www.themonkeyhouse.co

Menu: around 46,000 COP

content.title: W Bogota Hotel, a trend in modern luxury

introduction.small: The select W, located in the heart of old Bogotá, offers round-the-clock high-quality service combined with flamboyant architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: W Bogota Hotel, a trend in modern luxury

paragraphs.text:
Since its much-anticipated opening in December 2014, this opulent establishment has received the unanimous approval of fashion, design, and music celebrities as well as all those who count in this newly trending capital of South America. Centrally located near the embassies, restaurants and boutiques of the chic Santa Barbara quarter, W's outsized decor and volumes are inspired by the myth of Eldorado, when the conquistadors thought they had discovered a country filled with gold. Carefully crafted golden highlights shine from floor to ceiling. In the lobby, the magic is in the 1,200 golden butterflies in the gilding of a monumental chandelier. The same refined luxury can be found in the W Bar with its inspired cocktails.

In the same vein, the restaurant serves wonderful dishes in a brilliant showcase. More treasures gather on the 17 floors with 168 rooms and their colourful and avant-garde design, all equipped with ultra-modern technology. Not to forget, the famous W bed, which is of rare and exquisite comfort. Finally, for your wellness, the hotel has a spa, a gym, and fitness centre.

W Bogota Hotel
Carrera 9 # 115-30
Bogotá

+57 (1) 746 71 11

https://www.marriott.co.uk/hotels/travel/bogwh-w-bogota/

Rooms: from 480,000 COP

content.title: Estelar La Fontana Hotel, an elegant classic

introduction.small: Ideally situated in the north of Bogotá, in the upscale neighbourhood of Usaquén, this five-star property is perfect for a business strip or a holiday.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Estelar La Fontana Hotel, an elegant classic

paragraphs.text:
Dressed all in brick, it is unmistakable with its large glowing facade of British brown, where a uniformed staff will greet you. You have to take a few steps before discovering the elegant entrance hall, adorned with beige marble, sumptuous bouquets of roses, and huge glittering chandeliers.

Just another few steps on, the charming Glasgow Bar plays on the theme of English clubs with Scottish carpet, wood panelling, and fireplace. Nothing in the decor is lacking for a moment of pure relaxation with a cocktail or a Brazilian coffee. For a light meal, the restaurant offers Mediterranean cuisine served inside or on the terrace of the outdoor patio. A romantic and amazing place with a small chapel, which hosts wedding ceremonies, the hotel also has reception areas and 215 spacious rooms, decorated in classic style and good taste, all with the latest amenities. For sports, a spa and a fitness room are available.

Estelar La Fontana Hotel
Avenida 127, 15A-10
Bogotá

+57(1) 608 8080

https://en.estelarlafontana.com/

Rooms: from 299,200 COP

content.title: Salt Cathedral of Zipaquirà: a wonder of the world

introduction.small: The small colonial town of Zipaquirá is the site of an incredible underground cathedral carved in salt.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Salt Cathedral of Zipaquirà: a wonder of the world

paragraphs.text:
At a distance of 50 kilometres from the capital, the small colonial town of Zipaquirá clings to its colonial heritage, evidenced by its white and olive-green houses. The town is home to the surprising ‘Catedral del Sal', an exceptional underground salt cathedral, built in 1995. The original was built in 1954, but, on the verge of collapse, it was closed in 1992. Covering 10 hectares on three levels, the Cathedral was shaped from halite (salt) deposits, which formed there 250 million years ago, inside an active salt mine. At the top level, wide corridors serve the 14 chapels representing different stations of the Cross, bathed in a surreal atmosphere of blue, green, and red. The actual cathedral, 120 metres long and 22 metres high, is on the lower level. It is a unique site, classed as a UNESCO heritage monument, which can accommodate about 800 worshipers each Sunday for mass.

Catedral de Sal de Zipaquirá
Parque De La Sal
Carrera 6 Calle 1
Zipaquirá

+57(1) 315 760 7376

www.catedraldesal.gov.co

content.title: Guatavita, mother of all legends

introduction.small: Discover the colonial town of Guatavita, north of Bogota, and its famous Laguna where the legend of El Dorado was born.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Guatavita, mother of all legends

paragraphs.text:
A two-hour drive from Bogotá and perched at more than 3,600 metres of altitude, this is a popular excursion destination for tourists and Colombians alike. A replica of a typical Spanish village, Guatavita was built in the 1960s to accommodate the inhabitants of the ancient city, dislodged by the creation of the Tominé Dam.

Not far from these lovely white houses with terracotta tile roofs is Lake Guatavita, home of the legend of El Dorado. The story goes that the Muisca leaders, during their rituals, poured quantities of gold in the jade-coloured waters. The Guatavita Cacique (native chief) would travel by boat to the middle of the lake to throw gold coins and emeralds to appease the wrath of the demon. This mysterious lake was the object of the greed of Spaniards, who had long sought the treasure at the bottom of these mysterious waters. Today, the Colombian government prohibits excavations.

www.guatavita-cundinamarca.gov.co

content.title: Bike-friendly Bogotá

introduction.small: Biking is an ideal way to discover Bogotá and its secrets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bike-friendly Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
The capital has over 370 kilometres of cycling tracks, more than any other Latin American city. Commissioned between 1998 and 2001, with most of them specially built and reserved for bikes, they follow the large arteries, while others use the bus lanes or wind through parks. This is a perfect way to roam the streets of the historical colonial centre of La Candelaria, to ambulate through parks or perhaps stop at a market, and to discover the essential cultural sites like the Gold Museum and the Botero Foundation. It is also ideal for viewing the graffiti adorning the city's walls and reflecting on the creativity of the Bogotános.

On Sundays and holidays, from 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 p.m., the main avenues are closed to traffic and the streets are lined with fruit juice and food vendors, artists, and bicycle-repair stands. There are organised tours to discover the city, especially in areas where it would be unwise to venture alone.

Bogotá Bike Tours
Carrera 3, # 12-72
La Candelaria
Bogotá

+57 312 502 0554

www.bogotabiketours.com

content.title: The Orchids Hotel: a luxurious mansion in the historical district

introduction.small: This small eight-room hotel in the centre of Bogotá, a five-minute walk from La Candelaria, is an architectural splendour. Its eclectic decor both surprises and seduces.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Orchids Hotel: a luxurious mansion in the historical district

paragraphs.text:
Its purple facade hides one of the most refined and confidential addresses of the district. Upon your arrival you will be greeted in style by smiling staff in purple uniforms, the colour of the house. A neo-classical mansion built in 1892, it has been restored but still retains its period flooring, wood panelling, mouldings, and original stairs. The eight spacious rooms with generous ceilings are all differently and richly decorated, often with antique furniture and great style, and with names taken from opera. The Thais Suite is very feminine, with gold and purple patina. In the Barber of Seville Suite, wood and pleats are in the spotlight. Tristan and Isoldeis strong on gold and red Baroque upholstery. All of them are unique and enchanting.

At the Rossini restaurant, the menu designed by the chef Harry Sasson is served in a French 19th-century decor with 17th-century grand siècle dishes. The same luxurious elegance reigns in the Chopin lounge and the Oscar Wilde library. A magical spectacle that will not leave you indifferent.

The Orchids Hotel
Carrera 5, 10-55
Bogotá

+57 (1) 745 54 38

www.theorchidshotel.com/home/es

Rooms: from 316,800 COP

content.title: The B.O.G Hotel, gold-plated design

introduction.small: Located in the north of Bogotá, in one of the city's trendiest neighbourhoods, the B.O.G. is the ideal spot for those who love decor, trendy places and festivity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The B.O.G Hotel, gold-plated design

paragraphs.text:
This contemporary five-star hotel, with 55 rooms decorated by the Portuguese interior architect Nini Andrade, plays on colours and casual chic. There is no gaudiness here, just elegant emerald green and the shine of yellow gold. A subtle marriage that refers to Colombia's most precious treasures. The same warm harmony can be found in the spacious rooms, where every comfort has been included. The lounge bar, which is one of the most welcoming of spaces, with its wall of hanging panama hats and colourful cocktail menu, is a very popular place. In the restaurant, the chef brilliantly combines the flavours of Peruvian Amazonian influences around a fusion cuisine. Last but not least, are the rooftop pool, bar, and a panoramic terrace on the 9th floor, with views over the city and the surrounding hills. This is a favourite spot for fashion photo shoots and trendy parties.

B.O.G Hotel
Carrera 11 # 86-74
Bogotá

+57 (1) 639 9990

https://www.boghotel.com/?lang=en

Rooms: from 414,700 COP

content.title: The Gold Museum: a golden itinerary

introduction.small: The most captivating museum in Latin America, which maintains the largest collection of pre-Hispanic gold artefacts in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Gold Museum: a golden itinerary

paragraphs.text:
One of the largest and most fascinating museums in Latin America brings together over 55,000 gold objects of every major pre-Hispanic culture in Colombia. In an ultra-contemporary building on three levels, the visitor follows the historical route of gold, from its extraction to its use. Several exhibits are particularly impressive for the work of craftsmanship they present. This is especially the case for the magnificent raft offering, the golden Balsa Muisca raft, 48 metres long, discovered in 1969 in Pasca.

There are thousands of objects of all kinds, including masks, statuettes, crockery, ornaments, tiaras, brooches, rings, and hair clips, some displaying a striking modernity. These are the precious vestiges of pre-Hispanic cultures honouring the Quimbaya, Tairona, Muisca and Tolima civilisations that inhabited the region before the arrival of the Spanish caravels. Visiting this museum can take a good half-day alone for enthusiasts and the curious. A must-see while in the capital.

Museo del Oro
Carrera 6 #15-88
Bogotá

+57 (1) 343 22 22

www.banrepcultura.org

content.title: Graffiti Tour

introduction.small: A fascinating trip to discover the countless works of urban art in Bogotá.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Graffiti Tour

paragraphs.text:
Here, the walls burst with the colours of dozens of graffiti artists. In the colonial neighbourhood of La Candelaria, many walls are decorated with graffiti, usually made with spray cans. To enable urban artists to express themselves, the National Institute of Arts and the municipality of Bogotá have allotted large wall areas to them. And the artists take advantage of every square centimetre to show off their art, which is still regarded by some as an incivility. Beyond the banal tags, real works of art adorn many walls. To discover them, there is nothing better than a first-hand tour.

A two-and-a-half-hour tour leads you into several lanes of La Candelaria, among others, to raise awareness about this form of expression. This tour also allows you to discover when looking up, the characters carved from recycled materials by Jorge Olavé. An open-air art gallery offered to tourists!

Bogotá Graffiti Tour
Parque de los Periodistas
Bogotá

+57 321 297 4075

http://bogotagraffiti.com

content.title: 104 Art Suites Bogotá: for an extended stay

introduction.small: A design concept of 18 apartment suites. These are unique accommodations, decorated by contemporary artists for a stay of one night or several months.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 104 Art Suites Bogotá: for an extended stay

paragraphs.text:
Located in the central district of El Chicó, this property has several very elegant suites furnished like apartments. These ultra-luminous designer rooms are all decorated by different artists, some painters, others sculptors or designers. From classic, family, business, or penthouse suites, the surface areas vary from 35 to 65 sqm. They consist of a bedroom or two, a living room with fireplace, a kitchen, one or two bathrooms, and even a terrace. This is an ideal formula for a long stay.

You can benefit from all the services of a traditional hotel, including a reception and concierge service on the ground floor for bookings and so on, a restaurant open from 6:30 a.m. for your breakfast, and a Body tech Gym, which is one of the best gyms in the city. All these options are available with the added bonus of the opportunity of living as though you were at home, while discovering new artists.

104 Art Suites
Carrera 18A, 104-77
Bogotá

+57(1) 602 5959

www.104artsuites.com/en-us

Rooms: from 150,000 COP

content.title: Cartagena de Indias: an undisputed beauty

introduction.small: A jewel of the past whose appearance has not changed for centuries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cartagena de Indias: an undisputed beauty

paragraphs.text:
Known as the 'Pearl of the Caribbean', this phantasmagorical city is located in northern Colombia. After only an hour flight from Bogotá, you will find one of the first cities built in Latin America by the Spaniards, with its aristocratic neighbourhoods, popular streets, its exuberant architecture, colour scheme, and ornamentation. This is indeed where the galleons headed for Andalusian ports filled their holds with gold and emeralds. The picturesque buildings, perfect cathedrals, and colonial architecture create an unequalled historical atmosphere.

With its 17th-century forts, pastel-coloured houses, balconies overflowing with bougainvillea, and magnificent churches built by the Spanish, you will feel as though you have arrived in a novel by Gabriel Garcia Márquez. The white sandy beaches and clean warm water are another bonus to this charming city. The most pleasant and interesting city of Colombia is also one of the safest in the country.

Tourist Information
Calle 13 #1-25
Cartagena

+57 (5) 665 0515

www.colombia.travel/en

content.title: Gaira Café Cumbia House: experimental

introduction.small: A lively restaurant bar where music is queen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gaira Café Cumbia House: experimental

paragraphs.text:
A genuine institution in the Colombian capital since opening in 1998, the Gaira Café Cumbia House is always full. A restaurant, a bar, a concert hall, it is all of this at once, famous for its party atmosphere, its exuberant, constantly renewed playlist, and its bubbly decoration.

The idea for the place originated with the Colombian singer Carlos Vives and his brother Guillermo, and is prized by an eclectic Bogotano clientele, as well as passing visitors. It serves traditional cuisine and has an extensive cocktail menu with vintage notes as well as lighter drinks in a setting marked by a musical theme. It is the place to be on the weekend, when it is strongly recommended to reserve, because the Gaira is a festive place animated by the excellent house band, which improvises or revisits the classics. This address represents, more than almost anything, the renewal and dynamism of the city.

Gaira Café Cumbia House
Carrera 13 No 96-11
El Chicó
Bogotá

+57 (1) 746 26 96

www.gairacafe.co

Menu: around 65,500 COP

content.title: Bolívar Square, the heart of Bogotá

introduction.small: The central point of the historical district, the ex-Plaza Mayor is one of the most famous squares in the city and, indeed, the country.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bolívar Square, the heart of Bogotá

paragraphs.text:
The nerve centre of the city, built in 1539 under the name of Plaza Mayor, the square provides a framework for celebrations, masses, and bullfights. It was here that the 'cry for independence' rang out on July 20, 1810.

At its centre is a bronze statue of Simon Bolivar, cast in 1846 by Italian artist Pietro Tenerani, the first public monument in the city, where the hero of independence seems to watch over the population. It is lined with buildings of different architectural styles such as the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception and the chapel containing the tomb of independence hero Antonio Nariño. Here, too, is the Liévano, the Renaissance palace that houses the City Hall, the courthouse, and the National Capitol, which acts as the presidential palace. While most of these buildings date from the Republican period, they were built on the site of the old colonial buildings surrounding the square. Despite the administrative character of the area, we suggest you avoid walking alone at night.

Bolívar Square
Cll 42 con 7, Carrera 7
Bogotá

www.bogota.gov.co

content.title: Armando Records, in the heart of rumba

introduction.small: Three atmospheres, three floors, for one of the most popular clubs in Bogotá.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Armando Records, in the heart of rumba

paragraphs.text:
A stop at Armando Records, the specialist in mixing genres, is a must. You will immediately understand why when you get there.

There are three atmospheres for three floors, under one roof. A paradise for music lovers, Armando Records is one of the hottest clubs in town. The retro roof terrace offers a relaxed atmosphere for sipping a mojito while pressed into a 1970s sofa; the ground floor has a more festive mood, as a big party featuring Latin and electro sounds with very good DJs takes place in salons with mirror-covered ceilings.

At once bar, club, and concert hall, it attracts an audience of music and dance loving fashionistas. For a reasonable fee, you can also enjoy the Armando All-Stars, dedicated to reggae and salsa, which attracts a friendly clientele.

Armando Records
Calle 85, 14-46
Bogotá

+57 (1) 530 64 49

http://armandorecords.org/

content.title: Botero Museum: ample curves

introduction.small: The ideal place to admire the curvaceous figures of the famous Colombian artist Fernando Botero.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Botero Museum: ample curves

paragraphs.text:
In a large colonial mansion of the historical La Candelaria district, the Botero Foundation exhibits the magnificent personal collection of the famous painter and Colombian artist Fernando Botero, whose works were declared a heritage of national interest in 1979. This collection, which the artist donated to his country in 2000, was donated with the proviso that access to the museum remains free. There are women, men with moustaches, children, birds, and instruments a total of more than 120 sketches, drawings, sculptures, and paintings of buxom figures by the artist. The characters swell, the dresses puff, the instruments lose all sense of proportion. Botero's works seduce with their shimmering colours and their playful, exaggerated shapes. The collection also includes paintings by Pablo Picasso, Marc Chagall, Auguste Renoir, Claude Monet, Camille Pissarro, Joan Miró, Pierre Bonnard, and some sculptures by Salvador Dalí and Max Ernst in all, there are no less than 85 masterpieces by other artists of international fame.

A must visit for art lovers passing through Bogotá.

Museo Botero
Calle 11, 4-41
Bogotá

+ 57 (1) 343 1316

www.banrepcultural.org/museo-botero

content.title: Harry Sasson: a maestro at the oven

introduction.small: The most popular chef in Bogotá in a restaurant that bears his name.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Harry Sasson: a maestro at the oven

paragraphs.text:
Harry Sasson, whose name is well known to all gourmets, has put his talents to work at this eponymous restaurant. One of the best gourmet addresses in the city, it is ranked in the top 50 Latin American restaurants. It is housed in an ivy-covered, elegantly renovated 100-year-old mansion, and it attracts a clientele with fine palates drawn to this innovative cuisine with Asian accents. In the elegant dining room, brick elements have been kept next to classic leather furniture that leads on to an annex of very contemporary glass and steel.

The plates are masterpieces: crab bisque, chicken breasts and potatoes in rosemary, fresh grouper steak and crab or salmon dumplings, as well as national specialities, including ajiaco santa fereño, which is served in the chef's refined version with capers, sliced ​​avocado, puffed rice and a hint of sour cream.

Harry Sasson
Carrera 9 # 75-70
Bogotá 111221

+57 (1) 347 7155

www.harrysasson.com

Menu: around 155,000 COP

content.title: National Museum of Colombia: diving into culture

introduction.small: A complete overview of the heritage of the nation in a more-than-original building.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Museum of Colombia: diving into culture

paragraphs.text:
Set in 'El Panóptico', this building in the shape of a Greek cross was designed by an English architect to serve as a prison. It is now the oldest museum in Bogotá.

On three floors, doors with iron bars open onto 17 rooms that chronologically offer the archaeology, history, and art of the country. There is a wide range of works, objects, and testimonies, including the astonishing Muiscas mummies dating back 1,500 years, Francisco Pizarro's standard, and a room dedicated to Botero that traces his artistic life. The archaeology section chooses to show pre-Colombian art from the different regions along the river that runs through the whole country, the Rio Magdalena. In this section the entire period of the Spanish conquest is also presented. The historical part is based around three main themes: the role of the figure of the hero, the place of women in the creation of the nation, and the traditions and evolution in how the anniversary of independence is celebrated.

Museo Nacional de Colombia
Carrera. 7, 28-66
Bogotá

+57 (1) 381 64 70

www.museonacional.gov.co

content.title: Let's party!

introduction.small: Café Libro and El Gato Gris are riding a wave that really picks up the Latin American beat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Let's party!

paragraphs.text:
What is it that Bogotános prefer? Life, music, dance, salsa, and cumbia, a traditional Colombian rhythm.

The neo-Latin beat that is making Bogotá move is located in Zona T, Zona Rosa, and La Candelaria and Café Libro and El Gato Gris have become its institutions. On the plate, light and tasty empanadas. At the bar, more or less sophisticated cocktails. These establishments deliciously combine vintage armchairs, slates listing fresh tapas, and diabolically caressing rhythms. Colombians do not deny their culture; they exult in it.

In the bars and nightclubs of Bogotá, it is not uncommon to hear traditional music remixed with techno. To toast with style, they unearth local drinks that blend perfectly with regional flavours. A hypersensitive universe full of virtuoso musicians and colourful characters.

Café Libro
Carrera 11A #93-42
Bogotá
+57 (1) 218 3435

www.galeriacafelibro.com.co

El Gato Gris
Carrera 1A #12b-12
Bogotá
+57 (1) 342 1716

www.gatogris.com

Menu: around 46,000 COP

content.title: MAMBO: the modern art museum

introduction.small: Dubbed the MAMBO, the Museo de Arte Moderno de Bogotá focuses on different forms of art, from the early 20th century to the present.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MAMBO: the modern art museum

paragraphs.text:
Located in central Bogotá and inaugurated in the mid-1980s, MAMBO is housed in a brick building designed by the renowned Franco-Colombian architect Rogelio Salmona.

If you are interested in contemporary Colombian artists, this is the museum with the most impressive collections of painting and sculpture. Six exhibition rooms present the works of major Colombian artists like Botero, Negret, and Grau, as well as works by Picasso, Dali, Ernst and Warhol. The museum focuses on different forms of visual art (painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, video), from the early 20th century to today, and it has acquired a most perfect collection. A small cinema also shows Latin American art-house films.

Exhibitions change frequently, often honouring Latin American artists and always offering innovative cultural events. You come away with the feeling of having taken another stop along the road to understanding Colombian culture.

Museo de Arte Moderno de Bogotá (MAMBO)
Calle 24, 6A
Bogotá

+57 (1) 286 04 66

www.mambogota.com

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Bogota
content.introduction: Situated in the foothills of the Andes, at an elevation of 2,640 metres (8,661 feet), Bogotá is characterized by a temperate highland climate. Temperatures thus remain relatively stable year-round. It should be noted that Bogotá is blanketed in a hazy fog for more than 200 days a year. There are two rainy seasons, from March to May and from October to November, with frequent hailstorms that can be quite severe at times. The dry seasons normally run from January to February and from July to August.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Bogotá El Dorado International Airport
airports.description:
El Dorado, Bogotá's international airport, is located about 15 kilometres (9 miles) from the city centre. Calle 26 and El Dorado Avenue are the main access roads to the airport.
  • Two terminals:
    • El Dorado international terminal (Terminal 1, Air France)
    • Puente Aéreo domestic terminal (Terminal 2)
  • Getting from the airport to Bogotá and back:
    • By car
      • Access via Calle 26, about 20 minutes to the city centre.
      • Three parking facilities surround the terminal complex, COP 40,000 for 24 hours.
      • A central counter for car rentals is located on the first floor of T1.
    • By bus
      • TransMilenio operates a bus service connecting the airport to the central Bogotá in about 30 minutes.
    • By taxi
      • A fleet of more than 1,400 taxis (coloured yellow and white) is available for passengers, 24/7 for a fare of COP 14,400 per hour.
    • By shuttle
      • This free service operated by the airport runs buses between the terminals every 20 minutes from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +57 (1) 266 2000
  • Website: https://eldorado.aero/en/

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Bogota
transportation.description: Using public transport or taxis is recommended for getting around Bogotá, rather than rental cars.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Bogotá, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Instituto Distrital de Turismo (ITD, main tourist office in Bogotá)
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Carrera 24 No. 40-66, Barrio La Soledad, Bogotá
  • Telephone: +57 (1) 217 0711
  • Website: www.bogotaturismo.gov.co

information.title: Puntos de Informacion Turística (PITs, tourist information kiosks)
information.description:
At various locations throughout the city, you can obtain information and recommendations for your stay in Bogotá and its surrounding area. Listed below are the main addresses for the PIT's kiosks:

  • PIT Centro Histórico: Casa de los Comuneros Carrera 8 Calle 9 – 83
  • PIT Centro Internacional: Carrera 13 N° 26-62
  • PIT Terminal de Transportes Salitre: Diagonal 23 No 69 - 60 modulo 5 local 127
  • PIT Terminal del Sur: Calle 57 Q Sur N0. 65 F - 68 Autopista Sur Local 67

information.title: Colombia official travel website
information.description:
The official travel website of the Colombian government agency provides a wealth of information on Bogotá.

  • Website: www.colombia.travel/en

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. Bogotá counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Colombia. The following vaccines are recommended for travelling to Colombia:

  • yellow fever (required for entry to Colombia's natural parks)
  • booster doses for protection against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio
  • typhoid, hepatitis A and B, rabies (depending on the length of your stay)

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

 

  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: Avoid ice cubes, raw vegetables and shellfish.

information.title: Water
information.description: Bogotá is the only Colombian city where tap water is considered safe to drink. However, due to rather frequent contamination of water with microorganisms, bacteria, viruses and parasites, it is preferable to drink bottled water.

information.title: Altitude sickness
information.description: If you tend to be afflicted by altitude sickness (Bogotá is over 2,700 metre /8,000 feet above sea level) and/or have an increased risk of respiratory insufficiency, be sure to take the necessary precautions. Before you travel, talk about your plans with your doctor.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Spanish phrases that will make your stay in Bogotá a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: ¡ Buenos días ! (morning) / ¡ Buenas tardes ! (afternoon)
What time is it ?: ¿ Que hora es ?

Sorry: Disculpe (to say sorry)
Excuse me: Con permiso (to get past) / ¡ Por favor ! (to get attention).
How much is (…)?: ¿ Cuál es el precio de (…) ? /¿ Cuánto es ?
Where can I find (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo encontrar (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo comprar (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Bogota
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Bogotá each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: July 20: Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the declaration of independence from Spain on July 20, 1810.

events.title: August 7 : Battle of Boyacá  (national holiday)
events.description: Marks the key victory in 1819 of troops led by Simón Bolívar and Francisco de Paula Santander over Spanish forces, a turning point in the struggle for independence.

events.title: Second Monday in October: Columbus Day (national holiday)
events.description: Also commemorated as Día de la Raza ("Day of the Race") in several South American countries, this day pays tribute to the struggles against the European invaders having first arrived on their shores in 1492 and also marks the beginning of the mixing of peoples as well as the cultural richness engendered by this process.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Colombia
administrativeProcedures.description:
If you hold a French passport valid for at least six months beyond the period of your stay, you do not need a visa to enter Colombia, provided your stay will not last longer than 90 days (180 days if a visa extension has been obtained in advance).

For further information, visit the website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/
To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Bogotá and Colombia, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Colombia page of the U.S. State Department's travel Website: view information for travellers to Colombia

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government Offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to noon and 2 p.m. to 6 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Bogotá and throughout Colombia, tipping is not required though well appreciated, if the service is especially friendly and attentive. At a restaurant or café, a 10% tip is acceptable. Note that a gratuity, called a "propina voluntaria", usually amounting to 10% of the bill, is sometimes already included. If this is the case, there is no need to pay it twice!
